text:
Carlyle’s Rubenstein -- Business Should Be Concerned About Income Inequality Written by: Rhonda Schaffler 07/12/15 - 6:15 AM EDT Tickers in this article: CG 
NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Carlyle Group's co-founder and co-CEO said the U.S. has the worst income inequality since 1930, with wealthy people getting richer and poor people not advancing. 
David Rubenstein said at the Aspen Ideas Festival in Aspen, Colo., that "income inequality is an important concern of the business community, and should be an important concern. If people at the bottom...don't feel they can rise, that's a problem. In my case, I thought that I could always rise up by working hard and so forth, but many people now don't feel that's the case." 
Rubenstein said income inequality should be one of the issues discussed in the presidential campaign, along with how to increase economic growth and create "the kind of jobs that people want to have." He also said the candidates should be talking about how to keep the U.S. competitive against countries like China. Rubenstein is particularly worried about the low rate of GDP growth in the U.S. "I am concerned about it a bit because we haven't grown at 3% or 4% for quite some time, since the Great Recession, and one of the concerns that I have and others have is that we have an aging population and we have a large percentage of the workforce now not working." Rubenstein said efforts must be made to increase the labor participation rate, which remains at its lowest level since the late 1970's. 
As for his commitment to philanthropy, he was one of the original signers of The Giving Pledge, which encourages billionaires to give at least half of their fortunes to charity. Rubenstein said he hopes more billionaires will follow his lead, as well as those of lesser means.

"Philanthropy is an ancient Greek word that means love and humanity," said Rubenstein. "It doesn't mean rich people writing checks so you can do many other things to help people, with your time, your energy and ideas and you don't have to be fabulously wealthy to do that."
